webTitle: European markets slide after Eurozone private sector growth slows - business live

fields.bodyText: Disappointing eurozone manufacturing surveys combined with a number of other factors to send markets sliding, despite a positive report from the US. China was more uncertain, with the PMI survey better than some had feared but only showing tentative growth. On the geopolitical front there were worries about the possible repercussions of US air strikes on Syria. Pharmaceutical shares came under pressure after the US announced new plans to crack down on tax inversion, where US companies snap up overseas businesses and relocate their head offices abroad to pay less tax. The likes of AstraZeneca and Shire have been targeted in this way. In the UK, the FTSE 100 suffered its biggest one day fall since 3 March, for all the above reasons and with the added factor of a weak supermarket sector after poor growth figures from the latest Kantar Worldpanel survey. So the closing scores showed: The FTSE 100 finished down 97.55 points or 1.44% at 6676.08 Germany’s Dax was down 1.58% at 9595.03 France’s Cac closed 1.87% at 4359.35 Italy’s FTSE MIB fell 1.56% to 20,351.03 Spain’s Ibex ended down 1.33% at 10,801.8 In the US, the falls are more limited, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 38 points or 0.22%. On that note, it’s time to shut up shop for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we’ll be back tomorrow. Back again to the meeting between the Greek prime minister and German chancellor in Berlin. From Athens our correspondent Helena Smith reports: Today’s talks in Berlin were billed as yet another turning point in the crisis that has preoccupied Europe since exploding in Athens in late 2009. Although his fifth tete a tete with Angela Merkel, this was the first time that Antonis Samaras could impress upon her, in no uncertain terms, the fiscal progress Greece had made. And, racheting up the pressure to end one of the hardest phases of modern Greek history, impress upon her he did. Greece, he said, had not only outperformed fiscal targets -- pulling off a primary surplus, returning to capital markets two years earlier than expected, improving its international competitiveness and recapitalizing its banks - it had begun to emerge from six harsh years of recession. Finally, the debt-stricken country could “stand on its own feet” without the help of its troika of creditors at the EU, ECB and IMF. “Greece will soon propose it’s own framework of reforms for the coming years after the memorandum,” the leader insisted in what will go down as his first public attempt to define Athens’post-bailout era Greece, he told reporters after the meeting, was now so keen to end its dependency on outsiders it would seek to conclude financial aid from the International Monetary Fund early. “I believe that this process will … come to an end, actually before the timeframe originally envisaged,” said Samaras adding that Athens in no way required a third bailout to cover a looming financial gap in 2015. “We want normalcy for our country and we have showed that we can attain credibility.” Although rescue funds from the EU and ECB had been due to end this year, aid disbursements from the IMF had been slated to continue through March 2016. In a departure from times of yore, Merkel also appeared unusually conciliatory, praising Samaras for his leadership and confirming that Athens was making headway. “I know what difficult times Greece has gone through. But the first tender shoots of success are visible,” she said, emphasizing that Germany, the biggest contributor of rescue funds to date, was always ready to support the eurozone’s weakest link. But while Samaras clearly won his bid to buy time - and understanding - ahead of all-important presidential elections (which could in turn define the political landscape early next year), the meeting was as important for what was not said. The all-important topic of a write down on Greece’s debt load – at 175% of GDP unsustainable by any account – was kept firmly off the agenda. Much will now depend on the course of the troika’s next review of the economy. Denying that international auditors will delay their forthcoming inspection tour, the finance ministry announced that finance minister Gikas Hardouvelis would meet troika representatives in Athens on September 30. A rise in US interest rates could come in the first quarter of 2015, according to St Louis Federal Reserve president James Bullard. Bullard - who is a non-voting member of the Fed - made the remarks at a banking conference, repeating his earlier predictions. There was much talk about whether the phrase “considerable time” would be removed from the last Federal Reserve statement about the timing of a rate rise. In the event the words were kept in, and Bullard said he backed that decision. Meanwhile Bullard said the Fed should change the way it communicated its views on the future path of interest rates, according to Reuters. He said: I would like to get the commitment to move to something more data dependent. I think that’s really the way to go. And here’s a good comparison of the various PMIs from today, courtesy Markit: More detail from the Richmond Fed report: Overall, manufacturing conditions strengthened in September. The composite index for manufacturing moved to a reading of 14 following last month’s reading of 12. The index for shipments edged up one point, ending at 11, while the index for new orders also gained one point, finishing at a reading of 14. Producers remained positive about business conditions for the six months ahead. They expected solid growth in shipments and in the volume of new orders. The indexes for expected shipments and new orders ended at readings of 41 and 37, respectively, slightly below their outlook of a month ago. The US manufacturing sector expanded again in September, matching the previous month’s growth rate, according to data firm Markit. The initial reading for its purchasing managers index for manufacturing was unchanged from August’s figure of 57.9, the highest since April 2010. Markit’s Chris Williamson said: The flash PMI signaled another month of impressive growth of the US manufacturing economy. The third quarter as a whole has seen the strongest expansion since the sector began to recover from the financial crisis. We expect GDP to grow at an annualised rate of at least 3% and as much as 4% depending to a large extent on how the vast services economy fared in September. Meanwhile the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond’s monthly manufacturing index for September rose from 12 in August to 14. This sign of strength in the US economy means the market, while down, is doing better than had been expected in early trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is off 12 points, compared to forecasts of a decline of up to 50 points. That has helped European markets come off their worst levels, with the FTSE 100 now down 85 points, Germany’s Dax dropping 98 points and France’s Cac around 70 points lower. A quick catch-up. European stock markets are down sharply today, after weaker than expected surveys of private sector activity . The FTSE 100 is sharing in the selloff, down over 100 points. Details at 1.38pm BST The selloff was triggered by the latest data from Markit, which monitors activity at thousands of firms in Europe, and beyond. Markit’s composite PMI index fell to a nine-month low, indicating that European business activity is growing at the weakest level this year. Details at 9.15am. France was, once again, the eurozone laggard, with its service and manufacturing sectors both shrinking and losing jobs again. Markit says the French economy continues to weaken. The German data was mixed - service sector firms grew faster, but factory output slowed. Analysts say that the poor data has fuelled concerns over Europe’s economy. Richard Hunter, head of equities at Hargreaves Lansdown stockbrokers, said: “Some weaker European economic data and a resumption of geopolitical concerns following the Syrian air strikes are dampening sentiment. “In addition, recent profit warnings from the likes of Tesco and Tate & Lyle and concerns that future merger and acquisition activity may be crimped by the US authorities attempt to crack down on tax inversion are completing a stultifying cocktail. “Although presently difficult to see, the better than expected Chinese manufacturing data overnight and upbeat expectations for the impending third quarter reporting season are amongst the strands of optimism to which the bulls are currently clinging.” The UK stock market was also hit by the US clampdown on tax inversion, announced overnight, with several pharmaceutical firms including AstraZeneca dropping. In other news... Economists have warned that the UK government is on track to miss its deficit reduction targets. The latest public finance data, released this morning, showed that Britain borrowed slightly more this August than a year ago. Full story: George Osborne likely to miss deficit reduction target as UK borrowing rises Tesco’s share price has slipped below the 200p level for the first time in eleven years, as the crisis over its profit overstatement continues. Details. Over in Berlin, German chancellor Angela Merkal and Greek PM Antonis Samaras have been meeting. Merkel said there are “positive signs” from Greece, while Samaras repeated his pledge that Greece will post a primary budget surplus (ie, excluding debt payments) this year. And Greek cleaning workers have been holding a protest rally in Athens, as they push to get their jobs back. Photos here. And I’m now handing over to Nick Fletcher. Thanks all. GW The Wall Street Journal also attributes the sharp falls on Europe’s stock markets today on the slowdown in eurozone growth, and America’s clampdown on tax inversion. Tommy Stubbington writes: The weak data and setback for Europe’s prospects for takeovers are a “perfect combination” to put stocks under pressure, according to François Savary, who oversees around $10 billion of assets as chief investment officer at Swiss bank Reyl. “If you can’t count on M&A activity then you have to look back at fundamentals. Today’s data shows the recovery will be only gradual which will have an impact on people’s earnings expectations,” he said. The eurozone data are likely to put further pressure on the European Central Bank to come up with fresh stimulus measures to prop up the flagging recovery. ECB President Mario Draghi signaled Monday that the central bank remains open to aprogram of quantitative easing if inflation stays too low. “If there’s too much bad news the prospect of more from the ECB isn’t enough to hold up markets. We already had a lot of QE optimism in the price,” said Christian Stocker, an equity analyst at UniCredit. The FTSE 100’s 120 point slide means it is on track for its first triple-digit fall since early March. There’s still time to recover, though. Trading ends at 4.30pm. European stock markets are a classic sea of red, as this morning’s disappointing eurozone business activity surveys hit shares across the region. France’s CAC is the biggest faller, down 1.8% as traders in Paris digest the news that the French private sector is shrinking at its fastest pace in three months (details). Germany’s DAX is down 1.4%, after Markit’s flash PMI survey showed that its factory growth had slowed to near-stagnation. Markit’s warning that the eurozone is “a picture of ongoing malaise” has dented hopes that the single currency region could be clawing its way out of its recent stagnation. Gavin Friend, a strategist at National Australia Bank, says: “Although there was some relief that the French PMI number wasn’t worse, the fact that activity in Germany is only just expanding must be a worry” And in London,the FTSE 100 is now nursing a triple-digit loss, down 123 points or 1.8% at 6650. The Footsie fallers are led by Shire (-5.5%) and AstraZeneca (-5.2%), which look like less attractive takeover targets now Washington is determined to stop US companies shifting their tax base overseas. City analyst David Buik says President Obama’s threat to close up loopholes in the tax inversion system “really rattled investors’ cage”. Troubled Tesco is down 4%, while Sainsbury’s has lost 5% after this morning’s supermarket data showed both firms had suffered falling sales in the last three months. Geopolitics is also worrying investors; with the US launching air strikes on ISIS targets in Syria overnight. Joshua Mahoney, research analyst at Alpari, says: The escalation of the conflict will of course raise questions over the risk appetite of many within the markets, who are no doubt worried about a major war which appears to be unfolding. Speaking of Greece, a protest rally is taking place in Athens today. It is led by cleaning workers from the finance ministry who refuse to give up their fight to win their jobs back after being laid off in the government’s austerity drive. They are shouting slogans holding a banner reading ‘We raise our glove - rehiring now!’. The rally came after the Greek Supreme Court postponed an appeal ruling, scheduled for today, to rule on whether the cleaners’ dismissal was justified. Some news flashes from the meeting in Berlin between German chancellor Angela Merkel and Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras: MERKEL SAYS POSITIVE SIGNALS OF GROWTH ARE COMING FROM GREECE MERKEL SAYS ALSO POSITIVE DEVELOPMENTS IN GREECE’S IMPLEMENTATION OF ITS BAILOUT PROGRAMME GREECE’S SAMARAS SAYS WE WILL ACHIEVE A PRIMARY BUDGET SURPLUS IN 2014 Missed this earlier. Chuka Umunna, shadow business secretary, has weighed in on the Tesco crisis. The Labour MP told BBC Radio 5 Live that he was “deeply troubled” that Tesco profits had been overstated by £250m, and called it a “national interest issue”. “Whilst it may not, at first instance, be a public policy issue, it is definitely a national interest issue and this will have an impact on our business community. “I just hope that this is a one-off and this hasn’t been something that has been happening at Tesco over a period of time.” Over in Berlin, Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras is meeting German chancellor Angela Merkel. Our Athens correspondent, Helena Smith, explains that Samaras will play on fears that radical leftist Alexis Tsipras, the opposition leader, is lying in wait, ready to pounce if Greece is not cut some slack on the fiscal front. Tsipras, whose Syriza party is steadfastly ahead in polls, recently came out denouncing “Merkelism” and Berlin’s stubborn determination to inflict austerity on Europe’s weaker southern periphery. Although the German chancellor very much does not want Tsipras in power, Berlin also appears to be unwilling to let Greece off the hook in terms of resolving its 2015 fiscal gap (estimated to be around €12bn). It wants Greece to plug it with a third bailout because that way it can keep up the pressure on Athens with reforms. Samaras announced a whole host of tax relief measures, including breaks on heating oil, when he unveiled the government’s economic policy at the start of Greece’s political season earlier this month but it remains to be seen whether Merkel will allow some slack on the fiscal front to stop Tsipras coming to power. Tesco is coming under more pressure today; its shares have fallen another 3.8% to 195p, a fresh 11-year low. There has been a steady stream of analysts slashing their share price targets today, after seeing the company plunge by 11.5% yesterday. The latest grocery sales figures have added to the gloom. Kantar Worldpanel reports that Tesco shares are down 4.5% in the last 12 weeks. The news that finance chief Alan Stewart has been released from gardening leave three months early isn’t enough to compensate for the wider gloom. Instead, there is alarm that Tesco has been without a full-time CFO for so long, since Laurie McIlwee resigned in April. Martin Beck, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club, also reckons that today’s public finances figures, showing the deficit rose by £700m in August, are a headache for George Osborne: He writes: “August’s public finances data suggest that deficit reduction remains a grindingly slow process. “The chances of the Chancellor enjoying a fiscal windfall from the strong economic recovery in time for the Autumn Statement are looking increasingly slim. Rather than being in a position to offer some tax or spending sweeteners to kick in before next May’s General Election, he may be faced with the unpalatable choice of announcing further fiscal tightening or a slippage of deficit reduction plans. “The period from April to July had seen the fiscal year get off to a disappointing start, with borrowing running ahead of the deficit in the same period in 2013/14. August’s deficit has, if anything, worsened this picture, running £700m above the level in August 2013. With the effect of last year’s income shifting fading, near-stagnant pay growth seems to be playing the chief role in holding back tax receipts growth.” The market selloff is picking up pace -- the FTSE 100 is now down 90 points at 6684, a drop of 1.3%. Just four shares are defying the trend. EEF, the manufacturers’ organisation, says today’s public finance figures show that the government’s deficit reduction target is falling behind schedule. Economist George Nikolaidis writes: So are we on target? The short answer is no; as things stand the Chancellor is on course to missing his £95.5bn deficit target for the year. At the current rate, net government borrowing will come in at around £108bn and needs to drop faster if the Government is to hit its target before the end of the fiscal year and in time for the 2015 General Election. Slow progress in cutting the deficit is mostly down to muted wage growth constraining income tax revenues. Higher VAT receipts from a consumer-led recovery and stamp duty income from a booming housing market have failed to offset this drag. But it’s not all over yet. If earnings grow faster, the public finances will improve. Given that the deficit is highly sensitive to small changes in the growth rate of taxes and spending topped with the expectation that wages will soon pick up there is still scope for meeting this year’s targets. Here’s the full piece: Chancellor set to miss deficit reduction targets Britain’s weak public finances underline the damage being caused by the lack of wage growth, argues Newsnight’s Duncan Weldon (an ex-TUC chief economist). The latest UK public finances are out, and they show that Britain borrowed more last month than in August 2013, despite the strong growth over the last year. The Office for National Statistics reports that public sector net borrowing excluding public sector banks was £11.6bn in August 2014, an increase of £700m compared with August 2013. And since April, public sector net borrowing was £45.4 billion, an increase of £2.6bn on last year. Here’s the key chart (the blue line is borrowing this year and the blue blob is the end of year target): Central government receipts in August 2014 were £44.6 billion, an increase of £1.4 billion, or 3.2% than in August 2013: VAT receipts increased by £0.3 billion, or 3.2% to £10.2 billion; income tax related payments increased by £0.3 billion, or 2.4% to £11.3 billion; stamp duties (on shares, land & property) increased by £0.2 billion, or 24.1% to £1.3 billion; corporation tax increased by £0.2 billion, or 17.2% to £1.5 billion. But central government expenditure rose by 3.3% to £51.7bn, up £1.7bn (although that includes £800m of interest payments to the Bank of England on its holding of UK gilts) The Treasury claims that the UK is on track, despite the lack of progress in cutting the deficit so far this year. “The government’s long term economic plan is working, delivering economic security for hardworking people. Today’s Public Sector Net Borrowing figures continue to be in line with the budget forecast and borrowing is down by a third. But the job is not yet done which is why we must continue to work through the plan that is building a resilient economy.” Reaction to follow.... Numismatic news: European stock markets are in retreat this morning, as the disappointing PMI data hits confidence. France’s CAC is down 1.2%, after its private sector reported another month of falling activity. Germany’s DAX is down 0.8%. And in London, the FTSE 100 has shed another 67 points, or 1%, to 6705. It’s being dragged down by AstraZeneca (-5%) and Shire (-6%), as the US clampdown on tax inversion schemes means they are less likely to be taken over by American rivals. The Eurozone economy is “really struggling to get going” in the face of weak confidence and heightened geopolitical tensions, says Howard Archer of IGHS Global Insight. Here’s Archer’s take on the news that eurozone business growth has hit a nine-month low: Muted services and manufacturing output growth in September points to only a modest return to Eurozone GDP growth in the third quarter following stagnation in the second, while weakening output growth suggests that the fourth quarter is going to be another struggle. This is not what the ECB wants to see, especially as the surveys show still falling prices charged, albeit at a reduced rate in September. Oh dear, growth across the eurozone’s private sector has slumped to its lowest rate in nine months, fuelling fears over the strength of the recovery. Data firm Markit’s ‘flash’ measure of output at thousands of firms across the euro area has fallen back to 52.3, from 52.5, showing a slower pace of expansion. That means that Euro area business activity grew in September at the lowest rate seen so far this year, an alarming signal. Markit says the data means the eurozone only grew by 0.3% in the current quarter, while France stagnated again. Economist Chris Williamson says there is “a picture of ongoing malaise in the eurozone economy”. He pins some blame on geopolitical crises: “Concerns about the Ukraine crisis, related Russian sanctions and worries about the single currency area’s general economic plight appear to be having an increased impact on the eurozone economy. The danger is that the ECB’s efforts to stimulate the economy will prove ineffective in the face of such headwinds, which are exacerbating already-weak demand.” Europe’s factories were particularly poor this month, reporting little growth at all (dragged back by France’s ongoing weakness). And firms reported that new orders have fallen, suggesting more troubles ahead. It’s a generally grim picture, frankly. Markit says that employment was largely unchanged as companies held back from hiring extra staff due to the weak sales growth. By country, Germany reported faster than average growth (see details here), but the eurozone was dragged back by the ongoing downturn in France and slowing of growth elsewhere in the region. Output growth outside of France and Germany slowed to a six-month low, with order inflows registering the weakest rise for ten months. Oliver Kolodseike, Economist at Markit, says that September’s flash PMI report “paint a mixed picture” of the health of the German economy. Total private sector output continued to rise at an above average rate and employment growth picked up again, attributed in both cases to a strong service sector. However, new order growth slowed for a fourth month running and was the weakest in one year, suggesting that activity growth might slow in the near-term. “The introduction of a national minimum wage in January 2015 meanwhile weighed on service sector sentiment, with business expectations the lowest in nearly two years. “Moreover, recently weak manufacturing data have become one of the most conspicuous features of the fragility of a broad-based recovery. Production growth slowed further and new orders contracted for the first time in well over a year amid reports of a weakening economic environment. It remains to be seen if Germany’s goods-producing sector is in the midst of a slowdown or whether recent poor data present just a temporary soft patch.” The wider German private sector did grow at a slightly faster rate in September, with faster service growth making up for slower factory output. But Chris Williamson of Markit is concerned that factories reported that new orders are falling, suggesting a further slowdown ahead: Germany’s manufacturing sector has also slowed down, according to Markit’s PMI survey. The German manufacturing PMI, measuring activity across its factory sector, has fallen to a 15-month low of just 50.3, down from 51.4 in August. That’s close to the level separating expansion from contraction, suggesting that the sector almost stagnated this month. German service sector firms are doing better - their PMI rose to a 2-month high. Markit says that: the gap between manufacturing and services widened further in September. Unlike in France, where firms say they are cutting jobs, German companies reported another month of expanding workforces. They also reported that input and output prices increasing at slightly sharper rates, suggesting that deflation is not taking hold in Germany. Reaction to follow... Jack Kennedy, Senior Economist at Markit, says today’s PMI report (see last post) shows that France’s economy is deteriorating: “French economic performance weakened in September, as a return to contraction of the service sector outweighed an easing rate of decline in manufacturing. Anaemic demand continues to hold back the private sector, with further price cutting insufficient to prevent new orders from falling. Firms responded to the continued weakness by lowering employment at the sharpest rate since February. France’s private sector continues to contract as manufacturing and service sector companies suffer from falling output. The latest flash PMI report, from Markit, shows that France’s service sector stumbled this month, and manufacturing activity shrank again, although at a slower rate. Firms reported that they cut staff again, in the face of another fall in new business. Markit warned: Employment in the French private sector continued to fall in September, extending the current period of job shedding to 11 months. Moreover, the rate of contraction quickened to the sharpest since February. The data does nothing to ease fears that Europe’s second-largest economy remains in a mire of weak growth and low confidence. The Flash France Composite Output Index fell to 49.1, the lowest since June. Any reading below 50 suggests the sector shrank. Here’s the key charts: Reaction to follow.... Shareholders in Tate & Lyle may be feeling sour this morning. Shares in the sugar maker have crashed by 17%, after it hit the City with a profit warning. Tate & Lyle shares tumbled by 131p to 601p - a precipitous drop: Tate & Lyle slashed its profit forecasts this morning; due to tough competition in the sweeteners market (it sells Sucralose) and supply chain problems in America after last winter’s awful weather It announced an extra £30m of one-off costs, and cut its pre-tax profit forecasts to between £230m and £245m. That, the FT says, is 22% below City forecasts. In the City, shares in AstraZeneca have fallen by 4.5% after the US government announced a crackdown on American companies ‘inverting’ their tax structure. And shares in Shire, another pharmaceuticals company, are down 6%. Tax inversion was one driving force behind Pfizer’s attempt to take control of AZ, as it could have cut its tax bills by moving its domicile to Britain. Such accounting tricks may no longer be possible, with US treasury secretary Jack Lew declaring that: It’s critical that this unfair loophole is closed. Obama to target ‘inversion’ firms moving HQ abroad to avoid US taxes Luxury shoe maker Jimmy Choo has, as expected, announced plans to float on the London Stock Exchange. The company says it will raise funds to drive expansion into new markets such as Asia. Jimmy Choo chief executive Pierre Denis sounds rather upbeat, declaring: “Our future as a public company can only extend our reputation.” France’s statistics body has confirmed that the country’s economy stagnated in the seconds quarter of this year. INSEE also reported that industrial confidence remained flat this month. Troubled mother and baby chain Mothercare has launched a £100m rights issue, to cover the costs of revamping some stores and shutting other ones. Bad news from Tate & Lyle this morning. It has issued a profits warning, blaming supply chain problems and tough competition for its Splenda sucralose sweetener. Shares could take a pasting when trading begins.... After yesterday’s day to forget, Tuesday has begun a little better for Tesco. Marks & Spencer has agreed to release their outgoing CFO, Alan Stewart, from his contract early so he can join the supermarket giant and get to grips with the accounting problems that saw it inflate its profits by £250m. Stewart resigned to join Tesco in the summer, and M&S had been holding him to his contract. But as my colleague Sean Farrell explains, M&S has now softened its approach after a call from Tesco’s new CEO: As analysts accused Tesco of leaving its finance operation leaderless for months, Dave Lewis, Tesco’s new chief executive, called Marc Bolland, M&S’s boss, and asked for Stewart to be released early from gardening leave. Bolland decided decided that after more than two months out of M&S he was sufficiently detached and agreed. Stewart had been on ‘gardening leave’ since the summer. So he’s got plenty of practice getting his hands dirty, which could be handy given the mess at Tesco. The Wall Street Journal also reckons today’s Chinese factory data is a mild relief, given it shows activity accelerating (a little). But analyst Jeroen Blokland flags up reasons to be cautious: And Bloomberg’s Rishaad Salamat flags up other data suggesting China really is slowing. So, overnight, China’s factory output beat forecasts. But the data, from HSBC, also shows that manufacturers cut jobs, which will add to concerns that China’s economy may be weakening. Here’s AP’s take. Growth in China’s sprawling manufacturing industry unexpectedly ticked higher in September, according to a report Tuesday, easing concerns about the No. 2 economy’s recovery. HSBC’s purchasing manager index edged up to 50.5 this month from 50.2 in August, based on a 100-point scale on which numbers below 50 indicate contraction. Analysts had expected the reading to fall for a second month, dragged down by the slumping property market. August’s PMI reading was a sharp fall from the 18-month high of 51.7 reached in July. The modestly upbeat number comes after an official report earlier this month showed China’s factory output slowed sharply in August, which sparked fears momentum was fading and prompted some analysts to lower their full-year economic growth forecasts. China’s economic growth edged up in the April-June quarter to 7.5 percent after policymakers rolled out a batch of relief measures aimed at areas including railways and public housing. But analysts say further increments in growth will be hard to achieve without more government spending. “The picture is mixed,” with the report’s sub-indexes for new orders and new export orders improving but employment falling, said HSBC’s chief China economist, Qu Hongbin. “Overall the data still point to modest expansion. The property sector remains the biggest downside risk to growth,” he said. The report covered responses from 85-90 percent of 420 factories. The final version is due at the end of September. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the economy, the financial markets, business and the eurozone. Lots of data to wade through this morning, as investors wait for a new healthcheck from the manufacturing sector. Data firm Markit is releasing its “flash” manufacturing purchasing managers reports for France (8am BST), Germany (8.30am BST) and the Eurozone (9am BST). Those PMI readings should show whether there was any recovery in the French factory sector this month, or if Germany was hit by geopolitical worries. There’s also service sector data too. Jasper Lawler of CMC Markets has helpfully rounded up the predictions [50 = the cut-off point between growth and expansion]: At 8am French Manufacturing PMI is expected to improve slightly to 47 from 46.9 with services looking to slip back to 50.1 from 50.3 previously. At 8.30am BST, German manufacturing PMI is expected to fall back to 51.2 from 51.4 with services also seen declining to 54.6 from 54.9. Despite a general worsening of conditions in Europe’s two largest economies, the Eurozone composite PMI is expected to remain flat at 52.5. China’s factory PMI has already been released, and it beat expectations by showing a small pick-up in growth. More on that shortly too. There’s also an updated report on French GDP in the second quarter due shortly, which will probably confirm that its economy stagnated in April-June. In the eurozone, Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras will be meeting German chancellor Angela Merkel today in Berlin. Greek Reporter says: The meeting was arranged by the two leaders on the sidelines of the EU Summit on July 16. Samaras hopes to secure Merkel’s support for several Greek demands ahead of the troika’s return to Athens later this month. UK-wise, the latest public finance figures are released at 9.30am, showing how much Britain borrowed to balance the books in August. And I’ll also be watching for any Tesco developments, after yesterday’s shock news that it had overstated profits by £250m and suspended four senior execs. Tesco loses £2bn in value as profit investigation begins This one could run and run....
fields.standfirst:
Weak eurozone data, a US clampdown on tax inversion, and air strikes in Syria are all sending shares down across Europe

  • Early afternoon roundup
  • FTSE suffers biggest daily fall since March
  • UK deficit still growing
  • Greek PM meeting German chancellor
  • Eurozone business sector struggling; France weak again
  • Tesco sales fall fall further
  • AstraZeneca shares slide on US tax inversion clampdown
fields.headline: European markets slide after Eurozone private sector growth slows - business live
fields.body:
5.22pm BST

European markets fall sharply

Disappointing eurozone manufacturing surveys combined with a number of other factors to send markets sliding, despite a positive report from the US. China was more uncertain, with the PMI survey better than some had feared but only showing tentative growth. On the geopolitical front there were worries about the possible repercussions of US air strikes on Syria. Pharmaceutical shares came under pressure after the US announced new plans to crack down on tax inversion, where US companies snap up overseas businesses and relocate their head offices abroad to pay less tax. The likes of AstraZeneca and Shire have been targeted in this way.

In the UK, the FTSE 100 suffered its biggest one day fall since 3 March, for all the above reasons and with the added factor of a weak supermarket sector after poor growth figures from the latest Kantar Worldpanel survey. So the closing scores showed:

  • The FTSE 100 finished down 97.55 points or 1.44% at 6676.08
  • Germany’s Dax was down 1.58% at 9595.03
  • France’s Cac closed 1.87% at 4359.35
  • Italy’s FTSE MIB fell 1.56% to 20,351.03
  • Spain’s Ibex ended down 1.33% at 10,801.8

In the US, the falls are more limited, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 38 points or 0.22%.

On that note, it’s time to shut up shop for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we’ll be back tomorrow.

Updated at 5.44pm BST

4.21pm BST

Back again to the meeting between the Greek prime minister and German chancellor in Berlin. From Athens our correspondent Helena Smith reports:

Today’s talks in Berlin were billed as yet another turning point in the crisis that has preoccupied Europe since exploding in Athens in late 2009. Although his fifth tete a tete with Angela Merkel, this was the first time that Antonis Samaras could impress upon her, in no uncertain terms, the fiscal progress Greece had made. And, racheting up the pressure to end one of the hardest phases of modern Greek history, impress upon her he did.

Greece, he said, had not only outperformed fiscal targets -- pulling off a primary surplus, returning to capital markets two years earlier than expected, improving its international competitiveness and recapitalizing its banks - it had begun to emerge from six harsh years of recession. Finally, the debt-stricken country could “stand on its own feet” without the help of its troika of creditors at the EU, ECB and IMF.

“Greece will soon propose it’s own framework of reforms for the coming years after the memorandum,” the leader insisted in what will go down as his first public attempt to define Athens’post-bailout era

Greece, he told reporters after the meeting, was now so keen to end its dependency on outsiders it would seek to conclude financial aid from the International Monetary Fund early. “I believe that this process will … come to an end, actually before the timeframe originally envisaged,” said Samaras adding that Athens in no way required a third bailout to cover a looming financial gap in 2015. “We want normalcy for our country and we have showed that we can attain credibility.”

Although rescue funds from the EU and ECB had been due to end this year, aid disbursements from the IMF had been slated to continue through March 2016.

In a departure from times of yore, Merkel also appeared unusually conciliatory, praising Samaras for his leadership and confirming that Athens was making headway. “I know what difficult times Greece has gone through. But the first tender shoots of success are visible,” she said, emphasizing that Germany, the biggest contributor of rescue funds to date, was always ready to support the eurozone’s weakest link.

But while Samaras clearly won his bid to buy time - and understanding - ahead of all-important presidential elections (which could in turn define the political landscape early next year), the meeting was as important for what was not said. The all-important topic of a write down on Greece’s debt load – at 175% of GDP unsustainable by any account – was kept firmly off the agenda.

Much will now depend on the course of the troika’s next review of the economy. Denying that international auditors will delay their forthcoming inspection tour, the finance ministry announced that finance minister Gikas Hardouvelis would meet troika representatives in Athens on September 30.

4.06pm BST

A rise in US interest rates could come in the first quarter of 2015, according to St Louis Federal Reserve president James Bullard.

Bullard - who is a non-voting member of the Fed - made the remarks at a banking conference, repeating his earlier predictions.

There was much talk about whether the phrase “considerable time” would be removed from the last Federal Reserve statement about the timing of a rate rise. In the event the words were kept in, and Bullard said he backed that decision.

Meanwhile Bullard said the Fed should change the way it communicated its views on the future path of interest rates, according to Reuters. He said:

I would like to get the commitment to move to something more data dependent. I think that’s really the way to go.

3.20pm BST

And here’s a good comparison of the various PMIs from today, courtesy Markit:

3.15pm BST

More detail from the Richmond Fed report:

Overall, manufacturing conditions strengthened in September. The composite index for manufacturing moved to a reading of 14 following last month’s reading of 12. The index for shipments edged up one point, ending at 11, while the index for new orders also gained one point, finishing at a reading of 14.

Producers remained positive about business conditions for the six months ahead. They expected solid growth in shipments and in the volume of new orders. The indexes for expected shipments and new orders ended at readings of 41 and 37, respectively, slightly below their outlook of a month ago.

3.08pm BST

The US manufacturing sector expanded again in September, matching the previous month’s growth rate, according to data firm Markit.

The initial reading for its purchasing managers index for manufacturing was unchanged from August’s figure of 57.9, the highest since April 2010. Markit’s Chris Williamson said:

The flash PMI signaled another month of impressive growth of the US manufacturing economy. The third quarter as a whole has seen the strongest expansion since the sector began to recover from the financial crisis.

We expect GDP to grow at an annualised rate of at least 3% and as much as 4% depending to a large extent on how the vast services economy fared in September.

Meanwhile the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond’s monthly manufacturing index for September rose from 12 in August to 14.

This sign of strength in the US economy means the market, while down, is doing better than had been expected in early trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is off 12 points, compared to forecasts of a decline of up to 50 points.

That has helped European markets come off their worst levels, with the FTSE 100 now down 85 points, Germany’s Dax dropping 98 points and France’s Cac around 70 points lower.

Updated at 3.14pm BST

2.44pm BST

Early afternoon summary

A quick catch-up.

European stock markets are down sharply today, after weaker than expected surveys of private sector activity . The FTSE 100 is sharing in the selloff, down over 100 points. Details at 1.38pm BST

The selloff was triggered by the latest data from Markit, which monitors activity at thousands of firms in Europe, and beyond.

Markit’s composite PMI index fell to a nine-month low, indicating that European business activity is growing at the weakest level this year. Details at 9.15am.

France was, once again, the eurozone laggard, with its service and manufacturing sectors both shrinking and losing jobs again. Markit says the French economy continues to weaken.

The German data was mixed - service sector firms grew faster, but factory output slowed.

Analysts say that the poor data has fuelled concerns over Europe’s economy.

Richard Hunter, head of equities at Hargreaves Lansdown stockbrokers, said:

“Some weaker European economic data and a resumption of geopolitical concerns following the Syrian air strikes are dampening sentiment.

“In addition, recent profit warnings from the likes of Tesco and Tate & Lyle and concerns that future merger and acquisition activity may be crimped by the US authorities attempt to crack down on tax inversion are completing a stultifying cocktail.

“Although presently difficult to see, the better than expected Chinese manufacturing data overnight and upbeat expectations for the impending third quarter reporting season are amongst the strands of optimism to which the bulls are currently clinging.”

The UK stock market was also hit by the US clampdown on tax inversion, announced overnight, with several pharmaceutical firms including AstraZeneca dropping.

In other news...

Economists have warned that the UK government is on track to miss its deficit reduction targets.

The latest public finance data, released this morning, showed that Britain borrowed slightly more this August than a year ago.

Full story: George Osborne likely to miss deficit reduction target as UK borrowing rises

Tesco’s share price has slipped below the 200p level for the first time in eleven years, as the crisis over its profit overstatement continues. Details.

Over in Berlin, German chancellor Angela Merkal and Greek PM Antonis Samaras have been meeting.

Merkel said there are “positive signs” from Greece, while Samaras repeated his pledge that Greece will post a primary budget surplus (ie, excluding debt payments) this year.

And Greek cleaning workers have been holding a protest rally in Athens, as they push to get their jobs back. Photos here.

And I’m now handing over to Nick Fletcher. Thanks all. GW

2.10pm BST

The Wall Street Journal also attributes the sharp falls on Europe’s stock markets today on the slowdown in eurozone growth, and America’s clampdown on tax inversion.

Tommy Stubbington writes:

The weak data and setback for Europe’s prospects for takeovers are a “perfect combination” to put stocks under pressure, according to François Savary, who oversees around $10 billion of assets as chief investment officer at Swiss bank Reyl.

“If you can’t count on M&A activity then you have to look back at fundamentals. Today’s data shows the recovery will be only gradual which will have an impact on people’s earnings expectations,” he said.

The eurozone data are likely to put further pressure on the European Central Bank to come up with fresh stimulus measures to prop up the flagging recovery. ECB President Mario Draghi signaled Monday that the central bank remains open to aprogram of quantitative easing if inflation stays too low.

“If there’s too much bad news the prospect of more from the ECB isn’t enough to hold up markets. We already had a lot of QE optimism in the price,” said Christian Stocker, an equity analyst at UniCredit.

2.00pm BST

The FTSE 100’s 120 point slide means it is on track for its first triple-digit fall since early March.

There’s still time to recover, though. Trading ends at 4.30pm.

1.38pm BST

European markets hit by eurozone data and US tax clampdown

European stock markets are a classic sea of red, as this morning’s disappointing eurozone business activity surveys hit shares across the region.

France’s CAC is the biggest faller, down 1.8% as traders in Paris digest the news that the French private sector is shrinking at its fastest pace in three months (details).

Germany’s DAX is down 1.4%, after Markit’s flash PMI survey showed that its factory growth had slowed to near-stagnation.

Markit’s warning that the eurozone is “a picture of ongoing malaise” has dented hopes that the single currency region could be clawing its way out of its recent stagnation.

Gavin Friend, a strategist at National Australia Bank, says:

“Although there was some relief that the French PMI number wasn’t worse, the fact that activity in Germany is only just expanding must be a worry”

And in London,the FTSE 100 is now nursing a triple-digit loss, down 123 points or 1.8% at 6650.

The Footsie fallers are led by Shire (-5.5%) and AstraZeneca (-5.2%), which look like less attractive takeover targets now Washington is determined to stop US companies shifting their tax base overseas.

City analyst David Buik says President Obama’s threat to close up loopholes in the tax inversion system “really rattled investors’ cage”.

Troubled Tesco is down 4%, while Sainsbury’s has lost 5% after this morning’s supermarket data showed both firms had suffered falling sales in the last three months.

Geopolitics is also worrying investors; with the US launching air strikes on ISIS targets in Syria overnight.

Joshua Mahoney, research analyst at Alpari, says:

The escalation of the conflict will of course raise questions over the risk appetite of many within the markets, who are no doubt worried about a major war which appears to be unfolding.

Updated at 1.52pm BST

1.27pm BST

1.05pm BST

Photos: Greek cleaning workers protest

Speaking of Greece, a protest rally is taking place in Athens today.

It is led by cleaning workers from the finance ministry who refuse to give up their fight to win their jobs back after being laid off in the government’s austerity drive.

They are shouting slogans holding a banner reading ‘We raise our glove - rehiring now!’.

The rally came after the Greek Supreme Court postponed an appeal ruling, scheduled for today, to rule on whether the cleaners’ dismissal was justified.

1.01pm BST

Some news flashes from the meeting in Berlin between German chancellor Angela Merkel and Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras:

  • MERKEL SAYS POSITIVE SIGNALS OF GROWTH ARE COMING FROM GREECE
  • MERKEL SAYS ALSO POSITIVE DEVELOPMENTS IN GREECE’S IMPLEMENTATION OF ITS BAILOUT PROGRAMME
  • GREECE’S SAMARAS SAYS WE WILL ACHIEVE A PRIMARY BUDGET SURPLUS IN 2014

12.27pm BST

Missed this earlier. Chuka Umunna, shadow business secretary, has weighed in on the Tesco crisis.

The Labour MP told BBC Radio 5 Live that he was “deeply troubled” that Tesco profits had been overstated by £250m, and called it a “national interest issue”.

“Whilst it may not, at first instance, be a public policy issue, it is definitely a national interest issue and this will have an impact on our business community.

“I just hope that this is a one-off and this hasn’t been something that has been happening at Tesco over a period of time.”

12.04pm BST

Samaras and Merkel meeting today

Over in Berlin, Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras is meeting German chancellor Angela Merkel.

Our Athens correspondent, Helena Smith, explains that Samaras will play on fears that radical leftist Alexis Tsipras, the opposition leader, is lying in wait, ready to pounce if Greece is not cut some slack on the fiscal front.

Tsipras, whose Syriza party is steadfastly ahead in polls, recently came out denouncing “Merkelism” and Berlin’s stubborn determination to inflict austerity on Europe’s weaker southern periphery.

Although the German chancellor very much does not want Tsipras in power, Berlin also appears to be unwilling to let Greece off the hook in terms of resolving its 2015 fiscal gap (estimated to be around €12bn). It wants Greece to plug it with a third bailout because that way it can keep up the pressure on Athens with reforms.

Samaras announced a whole host of tax relief measures, including breaks on heating oil, when he unveiled the government’s economic policy at the start of Greece’s political season earlier this month but it remains to be seen whether Merkel will allow some slack on the fiscal front to stop Tsipras coming to power.

11.49am BST

Tesco shares fall under £2 mark

Tesco is coming under more pressure today; its shares have fallen another 3.8% to 195p, a fresh 11-year low.

There has been a steady stream of analysts slashing their share price targets today, after seeing the company plunge by 11.5% yesterday.

The latest grocery sales figures have added to the gloom. Kantar Worldpanel reports that Tesco shares are down 4.5% in the last 12 weeks.

The news that finance chief Alan Stewart has been released from gardening leave three months early isn’t enough to compensate for the wider gloom.

Instead, there is alarm that Tesco has been without a full-time CFO for so long, since Laurie McIlwee resigned in April.

11.00am BST

10.59am BST

EY ITEM Club: Osborne's fiscal windfall may be slipping away

Martin Beck, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club, also reckons that today’s public finances figures, showing the deficit rose by £700m in August, are a headache for George Osborne:

He writes:

“August’s public finances data suggest that deficit reduction remains a grindingly slow process.

“The chances of the Chancellor enjoying a fiscal windfall from the strong economic recovery in time for the Autumn Statement are looking increasingly slim. Rather than being in a position to offer some tax or spending sweeteners to kick in before next May’s General Election, he may be faced with the unpalatable choice of announcing further fiscal tightening or a slippage of deficit reduction plans.

“The period from April to July had seen the fiscal year get off to a disappointing start, with borrowing running ahead of the deficit in the same period in 2013/14. August’s deficit has, if anything, worsened this picture, running £700m above the level in August 2013. With the effect of last year’s income shifting fading, near-stagnant pay growth seems to be playing the chief role in holding back tax receipts growth.”

Updated at 11.00am BST

10.48am BST

The market selloff is picking up pace -- the FTSE 100 is now down 90 points at 6684, a drop of 1.3%.

Just four shares are defying the trend.

10.40am BST

EEF: George Osborne is not on track

EEF, the manufacturers’ organisation, says today’s public finance figures show that the government’s deficit reduction target is falling behind schedule.

Economist George Nikolaidis writes:

So are we on target? The short answer is no; as things stand the Chancellor is on course to missing his £95.5bn deficit target for the year. At the current rate, net government borrowing will come in at around £108bn and needs to drop faster if the Government is to hit its target before the end of the fiscal year and in time for the 2015 General Election.

Slow progress in cutting the deficit is mostly down to muted wage growth constraining income tax revenues. Higher VAT receipts from a consumer-led recovery and stamp duty income from a booming housing market have failed to offset this drag.

But it’s not all over yet. If earnings grow faster, the public finances will improve.

Given that the deficit is highly sensitive to small changes in the growth rate of taxes and spending topped with the expectation that wages will soon pick up there is still scope for meeting this year’s targets.

Here’s the full piece:

Chancellor set to miss deficit reduction targets

Updated at 10.42am BST

10.24am BST

Britain’s weak public finances underline the damage being caused by the lack of wage growth, argues Newsnight’s Duncan Weldon (an ex-TUC chief economist).

10.14am BST

UK public finances show no improvement

The latest UK public finances are out, and they show that Britain borrowed more last month than in August 2013, despite the strong growth over the last year.

The Office for National Statistics reports that public sector net borrowing excluding public sector banks was £11.6bn in August 2014, an increase of £700m compared with August 2013.

And since April, public sector net borrowing was £45.4 billion, an increase of £2.6bn on last year.

Here’s the key chart (the blue line is borrowing this year and the blue blob is the end of year target):

Central government receipts in August 2014 were £44.6 billion, an increase of £1.4 billion, or 3.2% than in August 2013:

  • VAT receipts increased by £0.3 billion, or 3.2% to £10.2 billion;
  • income tax related payments increased by £0.3 billion, or 2.4% to £11.3 billion;
  • stamp duties (on shares, land & property) increased by £0.2 billion, or 24.1% to £1.3 billion;
  • corporation tax increased by £0.2 billion, or 17.2% to £1.5 billion.

But central government expenditure rose by 3.3% to £51.7bn, up £1.7bn (although that includes £800m of interest payments to the Bank of England on its holding of UK gilts)

The Treasury claims that the UK is on track, despite the lack of progress in cutting the deficit so far this year.

“The government’s long term economic plan is working, delivering economic security for hardworking people. Today’s Public Sector Net Borrowing figures continue to be in line with the budget forecast and borrowing is down by a third.

But the job is not yet done which is why we must continue to work through the plan that is building a resilient economy.”

Reaction to follow....

9.51am BST

Numismatic news:

9.42am BST

European bourses in the red

European stock markets are in retreat this morning, as the disappointing PMI data hits confidence.

France’s CAC is down 1.2%, after its private sector reported another month of falling activity. Germany’s DAX is down 0.8%.

And in London, the FTSE 100 has shed another 67 points, or 1%, to 6705. It’s being dragged down by AstraZeneca (-5%) and Shire (-6%), as the US clampdown on tax inversion schemes means they are less likely to be taken over by American rivals.

9.32am BST

Howard Archer: Weak eurozone growth will alarm ECB

The Eurozone economy is “really struggling to get going” in the face of weak confidence and heightened geopolitical tensions, says Howard Archer of IGHS Global Insight.

Here’s Archer’s take on the news that eurozone business growth has hit a nine-month low:

Muted services and manufacturing output growth in September points to only a modest return to Eurozone GDP growth in the third quarter following stagnation in the second, while weakening output growth suggests that the fourth quarter is going to be another struggle.

This is not what the ECB wants to see, especially as the surveys show still falling prices charged, albeit at a reduced rate in September.

9.15am BST

Eurozone business growth hits nine-month low

Oh dear, growth across the eurozone’s private sector has slumped to its lowest rate in nine months, fuelling fears over the strength of the recovery.

Data firm Markit’s ‘flash’ measure of output at thousands of firms across the euro area has fallen back to 52.3, from 52.5, showing a slower pace of expansion.

That means that Euro area business activity grew in September at the lowest rate seen so far this year, an alarming signal.

Markit says the data means the eurozone only grew by 0.3% in the current quarter, while France stagnated again.

Economist Chris Williamson says there is “a picture of ongoing malaise in the eurozone economy”.

He pins some blame on geopolitical crises:

“Concerns about the Ukraine crisis, related Russian sanctions and worries about the single currency area’s general economic plight appear to be having an increased impact on the eurozone economy.

The danger is that the ECB’s efforts to stimulate the economy will prove ineffective in the face of such headwinds, which are exacerbating already-weak demand.”

Europe’s factories were particularly poor this month, reporting little growth at all (dragged back by France’s ongoing weakness). And firms reported that new orders have fallen, suggesting more troubles ahead.

It’s a generally grim picture, frankly.

Markit says that employment was largely unchanged as companies held back from hiring extra staff due to the weak sales growth.

By country, Germany reported faster than average growth (see details here), but the eurozone was dragged back by the ongoing downturn in France and slowing of growth elsewhere in the region.

Output growth outside of France and Germany slowed to a six-month low, with order inflows registering the weakest rise for ten months.

Updated at 9.25am BST

8.49am BST

Oliver Kolodseike, Economist at Markit, says that September’s flash PMI report “paint a mixed picture” of the health of the German economy.

Total private sector output continued to rise at an above average rate and employment growth picked up again, attributed in both cases to a strong service sector. However, new order growth slowed for a fourth month running and was the weakest in one year, suggesting that activity growth might slow in the near-term.

“The introduction of a national minimum wage in January 2015 meanwhile weighed on service sector sentiment, with business expectations the lowest in nearly two years.

“Moreover, recently weak manufacturing data have become one of the most conspicuous features of the fragility of a broad-based recovery. Production growth slowed further and new orders contracted for the first time in well over a year amid reports of a weakening economic environment. It remains to be seen if Germany’s goods-producing sector is in the midst of a slowdown or whether recent poor data present just a temporary soft patch.”

8.48am BST

The wider German private sector did grow at a slightly faster rate in September, with faster service growth making up for slower factory output.

But Chris Williamson of Markit is concerned that factories reported that new orders are falling, suggesting a further slowdown ahead:

8.39am BST

German factory growth hits 15-month low

Germany’s manufacturing sector has also slowed down, according to Markit’s PMI survey.

The German manufacturing PMI, measuring activity across its factory sector, has fallen to a 15-month low of just 50.3, down from 51.4 in August.

That’s close to the level separating expansion from contraction, suggesting that the sector almost stagnated this month.

German service sector firms are doing better - their PMI rose to a 2-month high. Markit says that:

the gap between manufacturing and services widened further in September.

Unlike in France, where firms say they are cutting jobs, German companies reported another month of expanding workforces.

They also reported that input and output prices increasing at slightly sharper rates, suggesting that deflation is not taking hold in Germany.

Reaction to follow...

Updated at 8.46am BST

8.31am BST

webTitle: Bank of England deputy calls for US co-operation over bank fines

fields.standfirst: Andrew Bailey calls for ‘cards on the table’ approach from world’s regulators, following FCA levy of £38m fine on Barclays
fields.body:
The deputy governor of the Bank of England has called for better co-operation with US regulators over the scale of fines being levied on banks to ensure they do not weaken their financial position.

Andrew Bailey said he wanted a “cards on the table” approach from regulators around the world.

“I am trying to build capital in firms and it’s draining out the other side (in fines and penalties),” Bailey saidat a banking conference.

Regulators in the US levy largr penalties than their UK counterparts, which on Tuesday fined Barclays £38m for failing to keep its clients’ money separate from the bank’s own assets – a record for that offence. When Barclays was fined £290m for rigging Libor in 2012, just £87.5m was levied by the UK regulator.

Since then, HSBC has been fined £1.2bn for breaching money laundering rules in the US while French bank BNP Paribas has been fined £5bn for dealing with countries that were subject to sanctions. Bailey’s intervention came as the Financial Conduct Authority accused Barclays of failing to learn the lessons of previous crackdowns on the financial industry after finding significant weaknesses in the bank’s systems.

The FCA said all firms needed to heed warnings put in place after Lehman Brothers collapsed in 2008 about keeping their clients’ money and assets separate from their own.

Barclays failed to do this and risked putting as much as £16.5m at risk for clients between November 2007 and January 2012 when it opened 95 custody accounts in 21 countries.

It is the second time Barclays has been fined for failing to protect customers’ cash. It was fined £1.1m in 2011 for similar misconduct.

Tracey McDermott, the City regulator’s director of enforcement and financial crime, said: “Barclays failed to apply the lessons from our previous enforcement actions, numerous industry-wide warnings, and exposed its clients to unnecessary risk. All firms should be clear after Lehman that there is no excuse for failing to safeguard client assets.

Barclays received a 30% discount on a proposed £54m penalty for agreeing to settle.

In May the bank was fined £30m for fixing gold prices, and it is fighting allegations of fraud made by the New York attorney general over how it marketed its “dark pool” trading system.

The City regulator also wants to fine Barclays £50m for reckless behaviour during its rescue fundraising in 2008, but the bank is fighting this claim. The Serious Fraud Office also investigating the fundraising.

webTitle: FTSE suffers biggest one day fall since March but Carnival cruises higher

fields.standfirst: Investors unnerved by poor eurozone data, Syrian air strikes and supermarkets
fields.body:
In a sinking market, with leading shares recording their biggest daily drop for nearly seven months, Carnival has managed to keep above the water line.

The cruise company reported a 4.7% rise in third quarter revenue and a jump in net income from $934m to $1.25bn, helped by higher demand for its Asian trips and higher onboard spending. It raised its guidance for the full year from the $1.6 to $1.75 earnings per share its predicted in June to $1.84 to $1.88. Carnival closed 6p higher at £24.43.

But overall the FTSE 100 suffered a 97.55 point fall to 6676.08, its worst performance since 3 March. Poor economic data in the form of disappointing manufacturing surveys from the eurozone set the tone, despite some relief that China and the US performed better than expected.

Geopolitical tensions also played a part, following news of the US air strikes on Syria.

There were a number of corporate factors. Supermarkets were weakened further by Kantar Worldpanel's latest report showing the UK grocery market grew at its slowest rate for more than 20 years. J Sainsbury lost 15p to 263.8p, while Tesco dropped another 8.5p to 194.5p despite parachuting in new finance director Alan Stewart several weeks early. A number of analysts cut their target prices, including Exane BNP Paribas, Nomura, JP Morgan and Deutsche Bank.

Meanwhile several healthcare shares were hit by overnight news that the US has announced new rules to reduce the benefits available to its companies buying overseas businesses for tax reasons.

This makes deals for AstraZeneca, pursued by Pfizer, and Shire, being acquired by AbbVie, and Smith and Nephew, less attractive, said traders. So AstraZeneca dropped 163.5p to £44.14, Shire was down 130p to £51 and Smith and Nephew was off 30p to £10.38. Simon French at Panmure Gordon said:

Overnight the US Treasury Secretary, Jack Lew, announced rules designed to limit recent growth in corporate tax inversions. This has profound implications for the UK biotechnology and pharmaceutical sector which has been the main focus of takeover activity. Well-documented UK-based inversion targets have seen their shares take a hit... However we remain bullish for consolidation in this sector that stands to benefit from a rapidly ageing population and a government that has fostered an accommodating corporation tax regime. A deal in the US Congress on tax simplification - a red line for Republicans to sign inversion legislation - would appear unlikely in an increasingly hostile environment leading up to and beyond the US mid-terms. As such we remain bullish that inversion opportunities have not vanished but must now adapt to a more hostile political backdrop.

Tate and Lyle slumped 122.5p or nearly 17% to 610p after a shock profit warning. The group said disruption in its supply chain and increased competition for its Splenda sucrolose sweetener in the second quarter would hit its full year results. It said it expected additional costs of around £20m in the second quarter taking the total for the first half to £40m. There would be an additional £10m of costs in the second half, meaning it now expected full year profits to be between £230m and £245m. Analysts had been expecting a figure of around £293m.

But with the Chinese manufacturing figures coming in better than expected, mining shares regained some ground, with Rio Tinto rising 49.5p to £31.08 and BHP Billiton 11p better at 1741.5p.

Elsewhere Go-Ahead accelerated 38p to £24.81 after Deutsche Bank moved from hold to buy and raised its target price on the transport group from £22.70 to £27.90.

Spirit Pub Group jumped 13.25p to 88.75p after brewer and pub owner Greene King, up 0.5p at 794p, confirmed a report in the Financial Times that it had made an approach for its rival, said to be worth more than £700m.

Finally stockbroker Panmure Gordon put on 14.5p to 155p as it announced first half profits grew from £0.3m to £1.9m and a gave a positive outlook for the second half.

webTitle: Centamin climbs after site visit to Egyptian mine

fields.standfirst: Analysts positive about prospects following trip to Sukari mine
fields.body:
One way of bucking the market slump appears to be to host an analyst trip and hope for positive feedback.

That appears to have worked for Egyptian-focused gold miner Centamin, whose shares have added 1.5% to 57.85p after a visit to its Sukari mine. Panmure Gordon's Alison Turner issued a buy recommendation on the company, saying:

Following an excellent site visit to Centamin's Sukari Mine yesterday we reiterate our positive stance on the company. We had been concerned that Centamin could miss this year's guidance; however, following the visit we think the miss (if any) is likely to be small. On the other hand that does not necessarily imply upgrades to next year's figures as the fourth quarter will benefit from some particularly high grades with grade reverting to the reserve average longer term.
Ramp up of the expansion is going particularly well. Whilst the new plant started production marginally later in the first half than the company had planned, the ramp up to capacity has been more rapid than expected and attention is already turning to optimisations to take the plant beyond 10m tonnes per annum. Following the expansion the company requires a 60% increase in the quantity of explosives (and a further increase beyond that as the stripping ratio increases). Whilst there appear to be no particular problems, given the political situation explosives are particularly tightly controlled and it is not clear how long the process may take. Whilst this is unlikely to impact this year's production, or next, insufficient stripping could build up to a constraint longer term if the permit is not in place by mid next year. Prior to yesterday's site visit to Centamin's Sukari Mine we had been slightly fence- sitting between two alternatives: either the company will miss this year's production guidance or an astonishing fourth quarter run rate will suggest upside to longer term forecasts. Following the site visit our conclusion is that there is probably an outcome between the two.

webTitle: George Osborne likely to miss deficit reduction target as UK borrowing rises

fields.bodyText: The chancellor is on course to miss his deficit-cutting target this year, according to the latest figures, giving him a headache in the run up to the 2015 election when the economy takes centre stage. Weak tax receipts pushed borrowing to £11.6bn in August excluding bank bailouts, £700m more than a year earlier according to the Office for National Statistics. Borrowing in the fiscal year so far, from April to August, was £45.5bn, £2.6bn higher than the same period last year. Economists said the poor start to the year had put at risk the Treasury’s official target of reducing borrowing to £95.5bn in 2014-15 from £105.8bn in 2013-14. Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight, said Osborne had “a mighty tough job” on his hands to meet the target. Martin Beck, senior economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club, said Osborne might be forced to use his autumn statement in December to announce more spending cuts or tax rises to meet his target. “August’s public finances data suggest that deficit reduction remains a grindingly slow process. The chances of the chancellor enjoying a fiscal windfall from the strong economic recovery in time for the autumn statement are looking increasingly slim. “Rather than being in a position to offer some tax or spending sweeteners to kick in before next May’s general election, he may be faced with the unpalatable choice of announcing further fiscal tightening or a slippage of deficit-reduction plans.” Samuel Tombs, senior UK economist at Capital Economics, said: “August’s public finance figures show that the coalition is still struggling to bring borrowing down as quickly as planned in the March budget. “If this trend is maintained in the remaining seven months of the fiscal year, then borrowing will come in at £105bn, some £10bn more than the Office for Budget Responsibility forecast in the March budget.” Higher borrowing was largely driven by weak income tax receipts, reflecting weak wage growth and distortions which flattered revenues in the early part of last year when bonus payments were delayed to take advantage of the cut in top rate tax to 45p from 50p in April 2013. The economy will be a key battle ground in the run up to the general election, with George Osborne likely to argue that it is only safe in the hands of the Conservative party. Ed Balls, the shadow chancellor, outlined his commitment to deficit reduction in his party conference speech on Monday, in a bid to reassure the public and businesses that Labour can be trusted to run the economy responsibly. George Nikolaidis, economist at manufacturing trade body EEF, said: “Borrowing needs to drop faster if the government is to hit its target before the end of the fiscal year and in time for the 2015 general election. “Slow progress in cutting the deficit is mostly down to muted wage growth constraining income tax revenues. Higher VAT receipts from a consumer-led recovery and stamp duty income from a booming housing market have failed to offset this drag.” The August borrowing figures were based on a new measure introduced by the ONS to bring them in line with European standards. On the previous headline measure, borrowing came in at £12.5bn, £1bn more than economists had forecast. Economists said there was still chance Osborne could meet the full year target if the public finances improved in the later part of the fiscal year. Nikolaidis said: “Most analysts seem to agree that forthcoming wage growth should greatly improve the Treasury’s balance sheet by reeling in more income tax. The chancellor is set to argue that one-off increases in income tax from the self-employed in January will also brighten the picture considerably.”

webTitle: AstraZeneca shares fall as Obama thwarts tax inversion deals

fields.bodyText: Shares in AstraZeneca and other potential takeover targets for US companies fell after the Obama administration announced measures to thwart tax-driven acquisitions of foreign companies. AstraZeneca was the subject of an acrimonious takeover approach by Pfizer earlier this year. The US company targeted AstraZeneca partly to move its headquarters to Britain and exploit the UK’s lower corporation tax rate. AstraZeneca rejected Pfizer’s overtures but the US firm kept its options open to make a second approach. Moving headquarters for tax reasons, known as a “tax inversion”, has proved politically contentious in the US as companies have lined up to find takeovers in lower tax regimes, particularly the UK and Ireland. The US rate of corporate tax is 35% whereas the UK, under reductions ordered by the chancellor, charges 21%, falling to 20% next year. Pfizer’s approach for AstraZeneca raised the political heat in the US over inversions, which are seen as largely artificial manoeuvres that leave day-to-day operations unchanged. The tactic became a test of White House resolve after Burger King agreed to buy smaller Canadian fast-food chain Tim Hortons last month to shift its headquarters to Canada. After failing to agree legislation with Congress, the Obama administration said on Monday that companies would no longer escape tax on US earnings by using internal loans, dividends and share swaps to restructure under foreign ownership. The changes will not apply to completed deals but are intended to deter further attempts to use what Jack Lew, the Treasury secretary, called an “unfair loophole”. AstraZeneca shares fell more than 5% as investors decided the White House’s move had made a further Pfizer bid less likely. Shares in Shire Pharmaceutical, which has agreed to be bought by AbbVie of the US, fell more than 6%. Smith & Nephew, also the subject of US bid speculation, fell 3%. Intercontinental Hotels, which has faced pressure from a hedge fund to agree to a tax inversion deal, dropped 1.7%. The Obama administration also hopes its measures will make it more difficult for US multinationals to avoid tax by parking earnings abroad without relocating their headquarters. Apple and Amazon have faced criticism for booking billions of dollars of revenues in overseas jurisdictions.

webTitle: EasyJet steady in market turbulence on hopes for dividends and French strike benefits

fields.standfirst: Budget airline boosted by European ruling and positive broker notes
fields.body:
As markets continue to tumble on economic woes, US tax inversion news as well as air strikes in Syria, there are some outperformers.

Mining shares continue to be among the few risers, with Fresnillo up 13.5p at 773.5p and Randgold Resources rising 61p to £43.26.

Overall the FTSE 100 is now down 89.52 points at 6684.11, or 1.3%.

Dipping lower but outperforming is easyJet, down 9p at £12.95. The sector has been supported by news that the European Court of Justice had cleared budget airlines to top up low ticket prices with extra baggage and seating charges.

In addition, a couple of brokers issued positive notes on easyJet. Robin Byde at Cantor Fitzgerald said:

EasyJet is trading well but the stock was weak through the summer along with the rest of the sector. We think this presents a good opportunity and upgrade to buy from hold.
Our target price is lifted to 1,600p from 1,500p. Management provided a useful strategy update at its Capital Markets Day last week. EasyJet will purchase extra A320s for expansion, target more business flyers and lift dividends payments. Meanwhile, the Flag Carriers continue to struggle to cut costs and revamp their own short-haul operations. We think easyJet and Ryanair will continue to take significant market share. We also calculate that easyJet can pay another special dividend, early in 2015. It is trading on a modest premium (8%) to the European sector, but at a 37% discount to its own historic PE.

Meanwhile Credit Suisse said the business could benefit from industrial unrest at Air France:

Air France's strikes driving market share to easyJet, suggesting a strong end to 2014: Air France KLM's confirmation that the past seven days of strike action have cost it up to €20m per day, before customer compensation and gradual operational recovery, highlights short-term earnings risk. However, we deem the bigger threat from industrial action at Air France to be that it drives incrementally more market share to easyJet. We expect easyJet to have prospered in France over the past week (around 15% of its business), supporting our view that easyJet can achieve the top end of its £540m-£570m 2014 pretax profit guidance range and we suspect that ongoing industrial challenges will be helpful to its ambition of increasing both business and leisure market share in France. We reiterate our outperform rating, with our target price of 1,837p suggesting 41% upside potential before a 3% dividend yield based on the new 40% payout ratio.
